fields.name: bg test
fields.background:
Currently, genetic testing is available in the United Kingdom (U.K) for both health and research purposes. In a health context, testing is available upon request by a medical practitioner via the National Health Service (NHS) or private health care, as well as online, without a request, through Direct to Consumer tests (DTC). Normative documents exist to help medical practitioners decide whether or not to request for a genetic test. Such documents include best practice guidelines such as “EO 1/s/a NHS England. 2013/2014 NHS Standard Contract for Medical Genetics (all ages)”.

Some of the DNA testing services available for health care include carrier testing, diagnosis, newborn screening, pharmacogenetic testing, prenatal testing, pre-implantation testing, predictive testing and genome sequencing. Genome sequencing, however, is only available to selected NHS patients as Direct to consumer tests online.
fields.standard_regulation:
Laboratories that conduct genetic testing for health purposes under the National Health Service are required to be assessed and accredited by the National Health Service, in collaboration with other bodies. Examples of which are provided below:

    Some NHS activity is carried out under the Human Tissue Authority (HTA) licenses.
        All collection and storage of tissue prior to DNA extraction.
        This process involves inspection
    Some NHS DNA analyses are outsourced to private companies and these particular operations fall under HTA regulation and inspection.
    The U.K Genetic Testing Network evaluates new genetic tests before member labs offer these to NHS patients.

NHS facilities are also accredited by the external body “United Kingdom Accreditation Service (UKAS)”.

There are also external quality assessment programs for DNA testing for health purposes such as those offered by the United Kingdom National External Quality Assessment Services (UK NEQAS) for Molecular Genetics.

It is unlikely that quality procedures exist for laboratories that conduct DNA testing for research purposes. The collection and storage of tissue, however, is under a license obtained from the Human Tissue Authority (HTA). It is not known if external assessment programs exist for these laboratories.
fields.dna_analysis_regulation:
The analytical validity, clinical validity and clinical utility of genetic tests conducted for health purposes are all regulated in the United Kingdom by the National Health Service.

The analytical validity, clinical validity and clinical utility of genetic tests conducted for research purposes, however, are not regulated at present.

There is also currently no regulation of the interpretation of the results obtained from DNA testing for health purposes in the U.K. There are external quality assessment programs, however, that cover this.

No regulations currently govern the interpretation of DNA data obtained from genetic tests for research purposes.
fields.dna_storage_regulation:
Currently, the U.K does not have any special arrangements for the data obtained from DNA testing for health purposes. This data is considered a part of patient records and as such, is regulated by the Data Protection Act 1998. At present, there is no further information about whether external regulations in this area exist.

The storage of data obtained from DNA testing for research purposes is not currently regulated, but this area is covered by some external assessment programs available to laboratories. For example, in UK Biobank, there are some regulations through the Biobank Ethics and Governance Framework and the UK Biobank Ethics and Governance Council that laboratories may decide to follow.
fields.dna_reporting_regulation:
In the U.K, laboratories that carry out testing for National Health Services can have their report of results signed off only by Clinical Scientists. Other laboratories also have Clinical Scientists but it is not certain whether other staff can also sign off on results reports in these laboratories.

These results cannot be directly shared with the patient if they are under National Health Services. Such a restriction does not exist for Direct to Consumer tests.

DNA data obtained from genetic testing can be shared with third parties in the U.K. In the National Health Service, there is a regulated system for sharing patient records through the Health & Social Information Centre (HSCIC). For some DNA analysis beyond routine testing, much of the work is conducted outside the NHS in research institutions. Lines between clinical investigation and research are blurred and DNA results may be shared with further third parties. For example, in the 100K Genome project, there may be criteria who the data is shared with for research purposes.

The sharing of DNA data obtained from genetic testing for research purposes can vary across organizations in the U.K. The UK Biobank and the UK10K project have different arrangements.
